Comment: This conflict is not about ethnic tribes arguing over land. Strictly speaking, modern 'Russians' is not an ethnic group; it's a 'superethnos' forcibly created out of different ethnic groups (incl. parts of Ukrainians, but lots, lots more) forged by political allegiance, high culture etc. In more familiar terms, being 'Russian' is like being 'British' (UK was far more honest with this, though). Also, Russian empire ('empire' being a key word) in all its iterations forced/s 'russianness' on everyone who could 'pass' (i.e. not too brown + an Orthodox Christian). So, people claiming themselves as 'Russians' in Crimea in 2001 really didn't mean anything; this self-identity was often based on fear, force of habit and other fluid things.  Also, Crimea was purged in 1945, everyone not 'Russian' enough (majority of then-population) was deported, and settlers from other places were forcibly moved to Crimea instead. To a much lesser extent, the similar processes are in place after 2014. So, for how long should you've been lived in some place to claim the moral right to decide the destiny of this land?
